Title: Parahippocampal projections to posterior auditory association cortex (area Tpt) in old-world monkeys
Abstract: Retrograde and anterograde tracing methods were used to study the connections between the parahippocampal gyrus and the posterior auditory association cortex (area Tpt) in the Old-World monkey. Nine monkeys received injections of tritiated amino acids in different areas of the parahippocampal gyrus, and three monkeys received injections of the retrograde tracer fast blue in area Tpt of the auditory association cortex. It was observed that the medial part of the posterior portion of the parahippocampal gyrus (area TH) gives rise to projections that terminate in layers I-III of area Tpt. Using complementary retrograde tracing experiments, the cells of origin for this projection were identified in layers V and VI of area TH. The findings reveal a direct structural coupling between auditory association cortices and a temporal region thought to play a role in learning and memory. These connections may form part of a neural system in the monkey that is related to acoustic learning and memory. Homologous systems in humans may be involved in auditory learning and language acquisition.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Region_Parcellation: Area Tpt, TE, TF,TF1 and TF2,TG, TH, OA, 28, 35
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation:
"Galaburda and Pandya' s (1983) map of the superior temporal gyrus was used for general guidance in terms of area Tpt topography, and their descriptions of this cortex were verified in each monkey. ...As Galaburda and Pandya (1982) note in describing area Tpt, layer III pyramids form distinct vertical rows or columns, and there is a relatively broad poorly defined layer IV that has indistinct borders with layers III and V. The differentiation of laminae V and VI is distinct in many locations and the latter is unusually wide.
The posterior parahpipocampal region on the ventral aspect of the temporal lobe is less understood and is described partially in Fig. 3A. The region is bounded rostrally by the entorhinal (area 28) and perirhinal (area 35) cortices and extends caudally to abut the ventral prestriate (OA) and the retrocalcarine areas. The parasubicular cortex delimits the posterior parahippocampal region medially, while laterally it is bounded by the occipitotemporal sulcus.
Classically, the posterior parahippocampal region has been parcelled into medial and lateral subdivisions, corresponding to area TH and TF, respectively (von Bonin and Bailey 1947). Area TF has been further subdivided into lateral (area TF1) and medial (TF2) regions (Brady and Van Hoesen 1984), as shown in Fig. 4."( p. 408)

@Injections.Citation: "In case 10 (Fig. 8), the injections consisted of a series of three penetrations made along the ventral margin of the posterior one fourth of the Sylvian fissure. ...Comparison with matching Nissl-stained sections for cytoarchitecture, and with the cortex of the opposite hemisphere, confirmed the location of label in area Tpt." (p. 413)

"Case 11 had an injection made by two penetrations into the cortex that forms the dorsal one half of the crown of the posterior-most part of the superior temporal gyrus. Cytoarchitectural study of adjacent sections verified its location in area Tpt." (p. 413)

"The injection in case 12 was aimed at the posteriormost part of the superior temporal gyrus, near the confluence of the lateral and superior temporal sulci. Analysis of the injection site revealed labeling in the medial part of the crown of the posterior superior temporal gyrus. Also involved, was cortex forming the ventrolateral bank of the posteriormost tip of the lateral fissure." (p. 414)
"Lateral view of rhesus monkey cerebral hemisphere, showing surface topography of three fast blue injection sites (case 10,11,12) in area Tpt." (p. 411, legend of figure 7)

@Methods_Animals.Comments: 8 rhesus monkeys and 4 cynomolgus monkeys were used with 9 TAA injections and 3 FB injections, but it is not stated which species recived which tracer substance.

@Injections.Citation: "In brief, aside a slight involvement of the parasubicular cortex anteriorly and the presubicular cortex at middle levels, the injection labeled nearly all of area TH. There was no evidence to indicate that area TF was labeled." (p. 409)
"Case 2 had an injection that labeled both the lateral part of area TH and area TF2." (p. 409)
"In case 3, the caudalmost part of area 28 and the rostralmost part of area TH were labeled." (p. 411)
"In case 4 the injection was located in the posterior part of area 28." (p. 411)
"In case 6 the injection involved the middle parts of area TF1." (p. 411)
"In one of these (case 8), the injection was confined to the anterior portion of area OA, medial to the occipitotemporal sulcus." (p. 412)

@Methods_Animals.Comments: 8 rhesus monkeys and 4 cynomolgus monkeys were used with 9 TAA injections and 3 FB injections, but it is not stated which species recived which tracer substance.

publication.title: Parahippocampal projections to posterior auditory association cortex (area Tpt) in old-world monkeys
publication.abstract: Retrograde and anterograde tracing methods were used to study the connections between the parahippocampal gyrus and the posterior auditory association cortex (area Tpt) in the Old-World monkey. Nine monkeys received injections of tritiated amino acids in different areas of the parahippocampal gyrus, and three monkeys received injections of the retrograde tracer fast blue in area Tpt of the auditory association cortex. It was observed that the medial part of the posterior portion of the parahippocampal gyrus (area TH) gives rise to projections that terminate in layers I-III of area Tpt. Using complementary retrograde tracing experiments, the cells of origin for this projection were identified in layers V and VI of area TH. The findings reveal a direct structural coupling between auditory association cortices and a temporal region thought to play a role in learning and memory. These connections may form part of a neural system in the monkey that is related to acoustic learning and memory. Homologous systems in humans may be involved in auditory learning and language acquisition.
